channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Claims Gains Near Bakhmut as Deadly Fighting Continues
item.description: Ukraine’s military said it had reclaimed about three square miles outside the eastern city of Bakhmut, which would be its first significant gains there in weeks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Thousands of Guns Turned in After 2 Mass Shootings in Serbia
item.description: The unregistered weapons were handed over to the authorities as the government vows to disarm the country after two mass shootings.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Joe Orovic
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral on Saturday in Malo Orasje, a village south of Belgrade, Serbia, for victims of a mass shooting in which eight people were killed.

item.title: Anxiety but No Signs of Chaos as Covid Border Policy Ends: Live Updates
item.description: Title 42, which lifted at midnight, had allowed agents to swiftly remove migrants on public health grounds. The immediate impact appeared to be less dire than many officials had feared.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

item.title: Turkey’s President Amassed Power. He Could Still Lose This Election.
item.description: Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has tilted the political playing field in his favor over the past two decades, concentrating power in his own hands. Still, he faces a stiff challenge in Sunday’s election.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers pass an election poster of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan at a market in the city of Kayseri last month.

item.title: From Rap Star to Engineer to Young Mayor Demolishing Swaths of Kathmandu
item.description: A music idol in his early 20s and then an engineer, Balen, 33, next won an upset victory as mayor of Nepal’s capital, inspiring a wave of young politicians. Now, he’s tearing down parts of the city.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Balen, wearing his trademark black-on-black blazer and jeans, paired with small, square black sunglasses, in Kathmandu, in November.

item.title: Iran Releases 2 French Citizens From Detention
item.description: Benjamin Brière and Bernard Phelan had been accused of spying, which they denied. They had protested their captivity with hunger strikes, and their families had fought for their release.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Families and friends of a growing number of Europeans imprisoned in Iran gathered in Paris in January to call for their release.

item.title: China’s Economic Needs May Take a Back Seat to Security
item.description: Xi Jinping wants to insulate China from perceived threats from the West. He also wants to promote the country as deserving of foreign investment and clout. Can he do both?
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: China’s foreign minister, Qin Gang, at a forum under the theme of “Chinese Modernization and the World,” in Shanghai last month,

item.title: Fighting Between Israel and Islamic Jihad: Where Things Stand
item.description: Exchanges of fire continued on Friday despite overnight mediation efforts for a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Walking through the rubble of a house that was hit by an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza Strip, on Friday.

item.title: Migrants Deported to Mexico Face Criminals and Predatory Officials
item.description: Those made to leave the U.S. face gangs and a Mexican asylum system where cases linger for years.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants near a wire barrier on the northern bank of the Rio Grande along the border between Brownsville, Texas, and Matamoros, Mexico.

item.title: A Crucial Question in Thailand’s Election: Can You Criticize the King?
item.description: Liberal voters have intensified their scrutiny of the Thai monarchy in recent years. Conservatives have responded with a campaign to defend the institution at all costs.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A policeman standing guard in front of a portrait of King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, during anti-government protests in Bangkok in 2020.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Risk Their Lives to Keep Weapons From the Black Market
item.description: They can’t track every shell, but at a time of heightened scrutiny in Washington they know they can ill afford slips with the big ticket items.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The 59th Motorized Brigade of the Ukrainian Ground Forces firing a howitzer at a Russian position in early May.

item.title: Chinese Dissident Sentenced to 8 Years After He Tried to Fly to His Dying Wife
item.description: The activist Yang Maodong said he had only wanted China to “fully realize authentic freedom, democracy, human rights and rule of law.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Erdogan Faces a Tough Vote in Turkey’s Election. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Sunday’s vote is the toughest for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan during his 20 years as the country’s premier politician. The withdraw of one of his three challengers made it even tougher.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election posters for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, his Justice and Development Party and the opposing Republican People’s Party, in Kayseri, Turkey.

item.title: The Biggest Explosion in the Cosmos Just Keeps Going
item.description: For three years, telescopes have monitored “one of the most luminous” events ever: a supermassive black hole consuming a gigantic cloud of interstellar gas.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.category: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society (Journal)

item.title: Ukraine’s Offensive Could Set Stage for Diplomacy With Russia, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: While exploring endgames, Biden aides say they reject any push for peace talks — including from China — that would freeze the current front lines and Russia’s gains.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training near Kyiv. The country’s leaders say they will not agree to talks until they have pushed back Russian forces.

item.title: What I’m Reading: Summer-Snobs Edition
item.description: Tales of status, those who have it and those who want it, are on my list.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Zack DeZon for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Pineapple Street,” by Jenny Jackson, is set among the ultrarich of Brooklyn Heights in New York City.

item.title: Wendy Sherman, the Deputy Secretary of State, Plans to Retire
item.description: She began her first diplomatic job 30 years ago, led talks on the Iran nuclear deal and grapples with China and Russia. She is also the first woman to be deputy secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Wendy R. Sherman has been a fixture in foreign policy circles in Washington and capitals worldwide as the go-to diplomat for tough negotiations with U.S. rivals and adversaries.

item.title: China Orders Tesla to Recall 1.1 Million Vehicles Over Braking Risks
item.description: Defects on certain Tesla models could lead drivers to step on the accelerator pedals for longer than necessary, increasing the risk of collisions, China’s market regulator says.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Claire Fu
item.media:description: Tesla Model 3 vehicles at a factory in Shanghai in 2020. China’s regulator has recalled several models manufactured between 2019 and April of this year.

item.title: A New Round of Middle East Fighting
item.description: The death of an imprisoned Palestinian militant leader on a hunger strike prompted new skirmishing.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Palestinian Islamic Jihad leader Khader Adnan during a 2015 rally in the West Bank.

item.title: It’s Called Eurovision. So Why Is Australia Part of It?
item.description: Australia has been one of the event’s biggest markets outside Europe. Since 2015, it has been a contestant, but that may end after this year’s final.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The Australian band Voyager performing at Eurovision, in Liverpool, England, on Thursday.

item.title: China Will Send an Envoy to Russia and Ukraine to Help Negotiate an End to the War
item.description: Li Hui, China’s special representative for Eurasian affairs, is expected to begin his trip on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Soldiers from Ukraine’s 72nd Mechanized Brigade firing at Russian positions in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last week.

item.title: Once an Evangelist for Airbnbs, She Now Crusades for Affordable Housing
item.description: Precious Price ditched her profitable business of renting home stays to tourists to combat the mounting housing crisis.
item.dc:creator: Martha C. White
item.media:credit: Lynsey Weatherspoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Precious Price, a former home-share host, sits in front of her tiny house that is in her Atlanta backyard. She now rents out her main house to local tenants, forfeiting lucrative short-term tourist bookings.

item.title: Cyclone Mocha Moves Toward Myanmar and Bangladesh
item.description: If current forecasts hold, the storm could be the strongest and most dangerous since 2010 to hit the area, which is the site of many refugee camps.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Judson Jones
item.media:description: A satellite image of Cyclone Mocha on Friday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The timing of Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier removing branches that had concealed a howitzer.

item.title: ‘I Don’t Know What the Future Holds’: An Afghan Family at the U.S. Border
item.description: Hours before the end of Title 42, a family of six from Afghanistan awaited their fate at the border wall in Tijuana, Mexico, after traveling through more than a dozen countries.
item.dc:creator: Noah Throop, Sarah Kerr and Caroline Kim

item.title: Zelensky, Citing Equipment Gaps, Says It’s Too Soon for Counteroffensive
item.description: Ukraine’s president played down the chance of an imminent military move, but the claim was greeted with some skepticism.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Shashank Bengali, Lara Jakes and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian marines removing branches that had concealed a howitzer before firing at a Russian target from a wooded position on Wednesday.

item.title: Sudan’s Clashing Forces Agree to Allow Aid In, but Not to a Truce, U.S. Says
item.description: Officials hope the agreement will allow the delivery of lifesaving aid and ease conditions for the millions of Sudanese suffering after nearly four weeks of fighting between rival generals.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Michael Crowley
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Sudanese Army soldiers in southern Khartoum, last week.

item.title: Karl Jenkins Sets the Record Straight: He Is Not Meghan Markle
item.description: Online jokesters claimed that Karl Jenkins was the Duchess of Sussex in disguise at the coronation. He sets the record straight.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.media:description: Karl Jenkins, a Welsh composer, attended the coronation of King Charles III because one of his harp compositions was being performed.

item.title: Kemal Dervis, Who Eased Turkey’s Economic Crisis, Dies at 74
item.description: Changes he spearheaded in 2001 helped avert disaster. He later led the United Nations Development Program.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: The economist Kemal Dervis in 2008, when he was in charge of the United Nations Development Program.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Guide to the Thai Elections
item.description: Today, our Southeast Asia bureau chief explains what’s at stake in the Thai election. Also, a court in Pakistan ordered the release of Imran Khan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Justin Porter
item.media:description: A voter casts his ballot during advance voting at a polling station in a school in Narathiwat, southern Thailand, on May 7, 2023, a week ahead of the May 14 general election.

item.title: Days After Crowning the King, Archbishop Condemns U.K. Migrant Plan
item.description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury and a member of the House of Lords, told Parliament that the government’s plan to deal with immigration is “morally unacceptable.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, at Westminster Abbey on the day of the coronation of King Charles III.

item.title: What Song Represents Your Home?
item.description: Tell us why it evokes the spirit of the place where you live.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: W.H.O. Ends Mpox Global Emergency
item.description: The virus was contained in most countries with a combination of vaccination and behavioral change.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Kholood Eid for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mobile mpox vaccination facility in Manhattan last fall.

item.title: Erdogan’s Election Prospects Take a Hit as a Challenger Drops Out
item.description: With Turks going to the polls on Sunday, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had hoped for a swift victory. But the departure of one challenger is likely to benefit his main competitor.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election posters for President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Kayseri, Turkey, in April.

item.title: Top U.S. Official Accused South Africa of Providing Weapons to Russia
item.description: The American ambassador to South Africa told reporters that Washington is confident a Russian ship picked up a load of weapons and ammunition near Cape Town in December.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The Russian ship Lady R, top left, docked at Simon’s Town Naval Base in Cape Town. A top U.S. official contended that the ship “uploaded weapons and ammunition.”

item.title: D.O.E.’s Loan Program Has a Lot More Climate Capital to Give
item.description: Jigar Shah runs a federal program that suddenly has a gusher of money to lend before the next election.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Jigar Shah, the director of the Department of Energy’s loan office program, speaking at the CERAWeek conference in Houston, Texas, in March.

item.title: Prince Harry Is Suing the British Tabloids. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Harry, the Duke of Sussex, has three ongoing lawsuits against newspapers. One of the cases went to trial this week and involves accusations of phone hacking.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: Pakistan’s Supreme Court Orders Release of Imran Khan
item.description: The Supreme Court said the arrest of the former prime minister in connection with a corruption case was unlawful. His detention this week had been met with protests across Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan celebrating a court ruling ordering him to be freed from jail on Thursday in Lahore, Pakistan.

item.title: Yellen Calls Invoking 14th Amendment to Raise Debt Limit ‘Legally Questionable’
item.description: The Treasury secretary warned that a default would lead to a “very substantial downturn.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen on Capitol Hill in March. “It’s legally questionable whether or not that’s a viable strategy,” she said on Thursday of a constitutional challenge to the debt limit.

item.title: UK Says It Is Donating Long-Range ‘Storm Shadow’ Missiles to Ukraine
item.description: The missiles, which are launched from the air, are the latest in a pipeline of military aid delivered to the country by Britain, the United States and other NATO allies.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A Storm Shadow missile on display at an air show in 2018 in Farnborough, England.

item.title: Bank of England Raises Interest Rates to 4.5%, Highest Level in 15 Years
item.description: The central bank lifted its benchmark rate a quarter point, to 4.5 percent, as part of its aggressive policy to tame inflation, but forecast that Britain was likely to avoid a recession.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bank of England in London. The central bank raised interest rates for the 12th consecutive time.

item.title: Abortion Access Keeps Winning Elections
item.description: But advocates can’t agree on a strategy to hold more ballot initiatives.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Lyna Bentahar
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Ohio woman signs a petition drive.

item.title: Interpol Asks for Help in Identifying 22 Murdered Women
item.description: Their bodies were found over the years in Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands. A new campaign aims to find out who they were.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Interpol has released details of nearly two-dozen cases, aiming to put a name to unidentified victims reaching back to 1976.

item.title: Israeli Strikes Continue Across Gaza Border Amid Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: After the militant organization Islamic Jihad fired hundreds of projectiles at Israel, Israeli forces stepped up its campaign of killing top commanders of the group in airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: The rubble of a building after an Israeli airstrike in Beit Lahia, in the northern Gaza Strip, on Thursday.

item.title: How Ana Ros, One of the World’s Best Chefs, Put Slovenia on the Culinary Map
item.description: Ana Ros broke through the boys’ club of fine dining, earning Hisa Franko in Slovenia two Michelin stars and a spot on the list of the world’s best restaurants.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Ciril Jazbec for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ana Ros, the head chef at Hisa Franko, a restaurant in the Slovenian countryside, is credited with popularizing Slovenian food in the global culinary world.

item.title: Luxury Imports to Russia Take a Detour Around Sanctions — Through Dubai
item.description: More than a year into Vladimir Putin’s invasion, the web of global trade has adjusted to Western sanctions, with a network of middlemen sending cars, electronics and more to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian-speaking sales agent poses for social media content at one of the dealerships in the car market on the outskirts of Dubai, United Arab Emirates, in March.

item.title: What’s Driving Record Levels of Migration to the U.S. Border?
item.description: The United States is trying to curtail border crossings as a Covid-era immigration policy lifts this week, but it has little control over the crises in Latin America that have upended the lives of millions.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants crossing the Darién Gap in September. As many as 400,000 people are expected to make this journey in 2023, according to the United Nations.

item.title: E.P.A. Proposes First Limits on Climate Pollution From Existing Power Plants
item.description: It’s the last in a string of major regulations proposed by the Biden administration to sharply cut the greenhouse gases produced by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Libby March for The New York Times
item.media:description: The regulations would set caps on pollution rates, which power plant operators would have to meet.

item.title: Natalee Holloway Disappearance Suspect to Face U.S. Charges
item.description: Joran van der Sloot is a suspect in the 2005 disappearance of the American teenager. He has been serving a 28-year prison sentence in Peru for a separate murder conviction.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Joran van der Sloot before his sentencing in a Lima, Peru, courtroom in 2012.

item.title: Ukraine Makes Gains Near Embattled Bakhmut, a First in Months
item.description: The leader of Russia’s Wagner paramilitary group confirmed the Ukrainian advance, and continued to air divisions among Moscow’s forces.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Traci Carl
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in an armored vehicle near the front line around Bakhmut on Monday.

item.title: Mexico Allows Tens of Thousands of Migrants to Travel to U.S. Border
item.description: In April, nearly 30,000 humanitarian visas were issued to migrants, according to government data, more than triple the monthly average in the first three months of the year.
item.dc:creator: James Fredrick
item.media:description: Migrants seeking immigration visas breaking through a security fence last week in Tapachula, Mexico, near the border with Guatemala.

item.title: David Miranda, Gay Rights Activist and Snowden Ally in Brazil, Dies at 37
item.description: Emerging from Rio’s slums, he helped Edward Snowden reveal classified documents and lobbied for his asylum before rising to his country’s Congress.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Miranda, at his home in Rio de Janeiro in 2019, after he was appointed to fill a vacancy in Brazil’s Congress.

item.title: In a Climate Trade-Off, Biden Backs Manchin’s Fossil Fuel Plan
item.description: The White House hopes that the approval of some oil and gas projects will speed the expansion of transmission lines for renewable energy.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin III, a West Virginia Democrat, is a strong supporter of coal and gas.

item.title: Biden Will Host India’s Prime Minister for State Dinner
item.description: For President Biden, next month’s visit will be an opportunity to draw India even closer, especially when it comes to countering China’s growing influence.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The visit with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India will also test President Biden’s observation that the world is at an inflection point where countries must choose between autocracy and democracy.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Unrest in Pakistan
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: The police fired tear gas at supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan during a protest yesterday.

item.title: Aboard ‘the Beast’ Train on a Journey From Mexico to America
item.description: Migrants slip onto a freight train in Mexico headed north to Ciudad Juárez, where most will try to cross into the United States.
item.dc:creator: Alejandro Cegarra and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants on top of a freight train during their journey toward the U.S.-Mexico border in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, on Monday.

item.title: ‘We Don’t Want This War’: Trapped in Khartoum as Combat Rages
item.description: Sudan’s capital city has become an arena for a battle between two generals vying for power, while residents brave shelling, looting and dwindling supplies of food, water, medicine and electricity.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Sudanese Army soldiers pass by tanks stationed on a street in southern Khartoum, last week.

item.title: Residents of Swiss Village Must Evacuate as Rockslide Poses Threat
item.description: Scientist say a rockslide could be imminent, but they can’t predict exactly what it will look like and whether the village of Brienz will survive.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The village of Brienz, Switzerland, on Tuesday. Residents have been told to evacuate by Friday because of the danger posed by the mountain.

item.title: Russia eases travel restrictions on Georgian nationals, in the latest sign of thawing ties.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday ordered the restoration of direct flights from Russia to Georgia and abolished visas for Georgian nationals.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Salome Zourabichvili of Georgia called Mr. Putin’s decision “unacceptable” and a “provocation.”

item.title: Imran Khan Arrest: Protesters Attack Pakistan’s Military
item.description: Regarded historically as a moderating force in the country’s politics, the generals’ reputation has withered under attacks from the ousted prime minister, Imran Khan.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: The police fired tear gas at supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan during a protest against his arrest, in Peshawar, Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: The British Monarchy’s Surprising Benefit
item.description: The coronation of King Charles III is a good time to look at what is useful about the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British royal family on the balcony at Buckingham Palace, following the coronation on Saturday of King Charles III.
